note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima

sp.speaker: Malfort.
sp.l: _AND as I told you Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I underſtand you,
Clarinda's ſtill perverſe.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Shee's worſe, obdurate,
Flinty relentleſſe, my love-paſſions jeer'd at,
My preſents ſcorn'd.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange a waiting-woman,
In her condition apt to yield, ſhould hold out,
A man of your place, reverend beard and ſhape,
Beſieging her.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You might adde too my wealth,
Which ſhe contemnes, five hundred Crowns per annum,
For which I have ventur'd hard, my conſcience knows it,
Not thought upon, though offer'd for a Joyinture:
This Chaine which my Lords Peſants worſhip, ſtouted;
My ſolemne hums and ha's, the ſervants quake at,
No Rhetorick with her; every houre ſhe hangs out
Some new flag of defiance to torment me:
Laſt Lent my Lady cal'd me her poor John,
But now I am growne a walking Skelliton,
You may ſee through and through me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Indeed you are much falne away.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: I am a kinde of nothing,
As ſhe hath made me: love's a terrible gliſter,
And if ſome Cordiall of her favours help not,
I ſhall like an Italian dye backward,
And breath my laſt the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: As I live you have my pity; but this is cold comfort,
And in a friend lip-phyſick; and now I think on't,
I ſhould doe more, and will, ſo you deny not
Your ſelfe the meanes of comfort.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Ile be hang'd firſt: one dram of't I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are not jealous of any mans acceſſe to her?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I would not receive the Dor, but as a boſome friend
You ſhall direct me, ſtill provided that
I underſtand who is the man, and what
His purpoſe that pleads for me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: By all meanes.
Firſt, for the undertaker I am he:
The meanes that I will practiſe, thus—

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Pray you forward,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You know your Lady chaſte Caliſte loves her.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Too well, that makes her proud.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Nay, give me leave.
This beauteous Lady, I may ſtile her ſo,
(Being the paragon of France for feature)
Is not alone contented in her ſelfe
To ſeeem, and be good, but deſires to make
All ſuch as have dependance on her like her;
For this Clarinda's liberty is reſtrain'd;
And though her kinſman the gate's ſhut againſt me;
Now if you pleaſe to make your ſelfe the doore,
For my conveyance to her, though you run
The hazard of a check for't, 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: It being for mine owne ends.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ile give it o're,
If that you make the leaſt doubt otherwiſe:
Studying upon't? good morrow.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Pray you ſtay ſir;
You are my friend: yet as the Proverb ſaies,
When love puts in, friendſhip is gone: ſuppoſe
You ſhould your ſelfe affect her?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Do you think Ile commit Inceſt; for it is no leſſe,
She being my couſin Germane. Fare you well ſir.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: I had forgot that; for this once forgive me.
Onely to eaſe the throbbing of my heart,
(For I doe feele ſtrange pangs) inſtruct me what
You will ſay for me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Firſt, Ile tell her that
She hath ſo far beſotted you, that you have
Almoſt forgot to caſt accompt.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Meere truth ſir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That of a wiſe and provident Steward,
You are turn'd ſtarke Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Urge that point home, I am ſo.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That you adore the ground ſhe treads upon,
And kiſſe her foot-ſteps.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: As I doe when I finde their print in the Snow.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: A loving foole I know it,
By your bloudleſſe-froſty lips: then having related
How much you ſuffer for her, and how well
You doe deſerve it—

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: How? to ſuffer?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No ſir, to have your love return'd.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: That's good, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will deliver her an Inventorie
Of your good parts: as this your precious noſe,
Dropping affection: your high-forehead, reaching
Almoſt to the crowne of your head; your ſlender waſte,
And a back not like a threſhers, but a bending
And Court-like back, and ſo forth, for your body.
But when I touch your minde, for that muſt take her,
(Since your out-ſide promiſes little) Ile enlarge it,
(Though ne're ſo narrow) as your Arts to thrive,
Your compoſition with the Cook, and Butler,
Fory Coney-skins and Chippings, and halfe a ſhare
With all the under-officers of the houſe,
In ſtrangers bounties, that ſhe ſhall have all,
And you as 'twere her Bailiffe.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: As I will be.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: As you ſhall, ſo Ile promiſe. Then your qualities.
As playing on a Gytterne, or Jewes Trumpe.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: A little too on the Viall.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I care you nothing.
Then ſinging her aſleep with curious catches
Of your owne making: for as I have heard,
You are Poeticall.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Something given that way.
Yet my works ſeldome thrive: and the main reaſon
The Poets urge for't, is, becauſe I am not
As poore as they are.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Very likely: fetch her,
While I am in the vaine.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Tis an apt time, my Lady being at her prayers.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Let her pray on.
Nay goe, and if upon my interceſſion
She doe you not ſome favour, Ile diſclaime her;
Ile ruminate on't the while.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: A hundred Crownes is your reward.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Without 'em—nay, no trifling. Ex. Malf.
That this dull clod of ignorance ſhould know
How to get money, yet want eyes to ſee
How groſſely hee's abus'd, and wrought upon,
When he ſhould make his will, the rogues turn'd rampant,
As he had renew'd his youth: A handſome wench
Love one a ſpittle-whore would run away from?
Well Maſter Steward, I will plead for you
In ſuch a Method, as it ſhall appeare
You are fit to be a propertie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yonder he walks
That knowes my worth and value, though you ſcorn it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If my Lady know not this—

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Ile anſwer it:
If you were a Nun, I hope your couſin German
Might talke with you through a grate, but you are none,
And therefore may come cloſer: ne're hang off,
As I live you ſhall bill: you may ſalute as ſtrangers,
Cuſtome allowes it. Now, now, come upon her
With all your Oratory, tickle her to the quick,
As a young advocate ſhould, and leave no vertue
Of mine unmentioned, Ile ſtand Centinell;
Nay keep the doore my ſelfe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How have you work'd
This piece of motley to your ends?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Of that at leaſure, Miſtris. Kiſſing.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Lower, you are too loud,
Though the fool be deaf ſome of the houſe may hear you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Suppoſe they ſhould, I am a gentleman,
And held your kinſeman, under that I hope
I may be free.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I grant it, but with caution;
But be not ſeen to talke with me familiarly,
But at fit diſtance, or not ſeen at all,
It were the better: you know my Ladies humour,
Shee is all honour, and compos'd of goodneſſe,
(As ſhe pretends) and you having no buſineſſe,
How jealous may ſhe grow?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will be rul'd.
But you have promis'd, and I muſt enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: We ſhall finde time for that; you are too haſtie:
Make your ſelfe fit, and I ſhall make occaſion,
Deli●eration makes beſt in that buſineſſe,
And contents every way.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: But you muſt feed
This fooliſh Steward with ſome ſhadow of
A future favour, that we may preſerve him
To be our inſtrument.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Hang him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: For my ſake ſweet,
I undertook to ſpeak for him, any bauble,
Or ſlight employment in the way of ſervice,
Will feed him fat.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Leave him to me, Enter Malfort.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: She comes. My Lady.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I will ſatisfie her.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How far have you prevail'd?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Obſerve.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Mounſieur Malfort.
I muſt be briefe, my couſin hath ſpoke much
In your behalfe, and to give you ſome proof,
I entertaine you as my ſervant,
You ſhall have the grace.

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.l: Upon your knee receive it,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And take it a ſpeciall favour from me,
To tye my ſhooe.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: I am ore-joy'd.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Good reaſon.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You may come higher in time.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No more, the Lady. Enter Caliſta.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: She frownes.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I thanke you for this viſit couſin,
But without leave hereafter from my Lady,
I dare not change diſcourſe with you.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Pray you take your mornings draught.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I thank you: Exeunt Leon. Malfort.
Happineſſe attend your honour.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Who gave warrant to this private parle?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My innocence; I hope
My conference with a kinſeman cannot call
Your anger on me.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Kinſman? Let me have
No more of this, as you deſire you may continue mine.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Why Madam (under pardon)
Suppoſe him otherwiſe: yet comming in
A lawfull way it is excuſable.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I grant you are made of pureneſſe,
And that your tenderneſſe of honour holds
The ſoveraigntie o're your paſſions. Yet you have
A noble Husband, with allow'd embraces,
To quench laſcivious fires, ſhould ſuch flame in you,
As I muſt ne're believe. Were I the wife
Of one that could but zanie brave Cleander,
Even in his leaſt perfections, (excuſe
My ore-bold inference) I ſhould deſire
To meet no other object.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You grow ſaucie. Doe I look further?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: No, deare Madam: and
It is my wonder or aſtoniſhment rather,
You could deny the ſervice of Liſandar;
A man without a rivall: one the King
And Kingdome gazes on with admiration,
For all the excellencies a mother could
Wiſh in her onely ſonne.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Did not mine honour
And Obligation to Cleander, force me
To be deafe to his complaints?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis true; but yet
Your rigor to command him from your preſence,
Argu'd but ſmall compaſſion; the Groves
Witneſſe his grievous ſufferings, your faire name
Upon the rhinde of every gentle Poplar,
And amorous Myrtle, (trees to Venus ſacred)
With adoration carv'd, and kneel'd unto,
This you (unſeen of him) both ſaw and heard
Without compaſſion, and what receiv'd he
For his true ſorrowes? but the heavy knowledge,
That 'twas your peremptory will and pleaſure,
(How e're my Lord liv'd in him) he ſhould quit
Your ſight and houſe for ever.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I confeſſe I gave him a ſtrong potion to worke
Upon his hot bloud, and I hope 'twill cure him:
Yet I could wiſh the cauſe had concern'd others,
I might have met his ſorrowes with more pittie;
At leaſt have lent ſome counſell to his miſeries,
Though now for honour ſake, I muſt forget him,
And never know the name more of Liſander:
Yet in my juſtice I am bound to grant him,
(Laying his love aſide) moſt truely noble.
But mention him no more, this inſtant houre
My brother Lidian, new return'd from travaile,
And his brave friend Clarange, long ſince rivalls
For faire and rich Olinda, are to heare
Her abſolute determination, whom
She pleaſes to elect: ſee all things ready
To entertain 'em: and on my diſpleaſure
No more words of Liſander.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: She endures to heare him nam'd by no tongue but her owne:
How e're ſhe carries it, I know ſhe loves him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hard nature: hard condition of poore women!
That where we are moſt ſu'd too, we muſt flye moſt.
The trees grow up, and mixe together freely,
The Oke not envious of the ſailing Cedart
The luſtie Vine not jealous of the Ivie
Becauſe ſhe clips the Elme; the flowers ſhoot up,
And wantonly kiſſe one another hourely,
This bloſſome glorying in the others beauty,
And yet they ſmell as ſweet, and look as lovely:
But we are ty'd to grow alone. O honour,
Thou hard Law to our lives, chaine to our freedomes;
He that invented thee had many curſes;
How is my ſoule divided? O Cleander,
My beſt deſerving husband! O Liſander!
The trueſt lover that e're ſacrific'd
To Cupid againſt Hymen: O mine honour;
A Tyrant, yet to be obey'd, and 'tis
But juſtice we ſhould thy ſtrict Lawes endure,
Since our obedience to thee keeps us pure. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How inſupportable the difference
Of deare friends is, the ſorrow that I feele
For my Liſanders abſence, one that ſtampes
A reverend print on friendſhip, does aſſure me
You are rivals for a Lady, a faire Lady,
And in the acquiſition of her favours,
Hazard the cutting of that Gordion knot
From your firſt childhood to this preſent houre,
By all the tyes of love and amity faſtend,
I am bleſt in a wife (heaven make me thankefull)
Inferiour to none (ſans pride I ſpeake it)
Yet if I were a free-man, and could purchaſe
At any rate the certainty to enjoy
Liſanders converſation while I liv'd,
Forgive me my Caliſte and the Sexe,
I never would ſeeke change.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: My Lord and brother,
I da e not blame your choice, Liſanders worth,
Being a Miſtris to be ever courted;
Nor ſhall our equall ſuit to faire Olinda
Weaken, but adde ſtrength to our true affection,
With zeale ſo long continued.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: When we know
Whom ſhe prefers, as ſhe can chooſe but one,
By our ſo long tride friendſhip we have vow'd
The other ſhall deſiſt.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: 'Tis yet your purpoſe,
But how this reſolution will hold
In him that is refus'd, is not alone
Doubtfull, but dangerous.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: The rich heire is come ſir.

sp.speaker: Cleand.
sp.l: Madam Olinda.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Yes ſir, and makes choice,
After ſome little conference with my Lady,
Of this room to give anſwer to her ſuitors.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Already both look pale, between your hopes
To win the prize, and your deſpaire to loſe
What you contended for.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: No ſir, I am arm'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I confident of my intereſt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ile beleeve ye when you have endur'd the teſt.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Is not your garter
Unty'd? you promis'd that I ſhould grow higher
In doing you ſervice.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Fall off or you loſe mee. Exit Malf.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Nay take your place, no Paris now ſits judge
On the contending goddeſſes. You are
The Deitie that muſt make curſt or happy,
One of your languiſhing ſervants.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I thus look with equal eyes on both, either deſerves
A fairer fortune then they can in reaſon
Hope for from me; from Lidian I expect,
When I have made him mine, all pleaſures that
The ſweetneſſe of his manners, youth, and vertues
Can give aſſurance of: but turning this way
To brave Clarange, in his face appeares
A kinde of majeſty which ſhould command,
Not ſue for favour. If the faireſt Lady
Of France, ſet forth with natures beſt endowments
Nay ſhould I adde a Princeſſe of the bloud,
Did now lay claime to either for a husband,
So vehement my affection is to both,
My envie at her happineſſe would kill me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The ſtrangeſt love I ever heard.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You can enjoy but one.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The more I ſay the merrier.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Witneſſe theſe teares I love both, as I know
You burne with equall flames, and ſo affect me;
Abundance makes me poore; ſuch is the hard
Condition of my fortune; be your owne judges;
If I ſhould favour both, 'twill taint my honour,
And that before my life I muſt prefer,
If one I leane to, the other is diſvalewed;
You are fierie both, and love will make you warmer,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The warmer ſtill the fitter. You are a foole Lady.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: To what may love, and the devill jealouſie ſpur you
Is too apparent: my name's cal'd in queſtion:
Your ſwords flie out, your angers range at large:
Then what a murther of my modeſty followes?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Take heed of that by any meanes: O innocent,
That will deny a bleſſing when 'tis offer'd,
Would I were murther'd ſo, I would thank my modeſty.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What pauſe you on?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: It is at length reſolved.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: We are on the Rack, uncertain expectation,
The greateſt torture.

sp.speaker: Lidian.
sp.l: Command what you pleaſe,
And you ſhall ſee how willingly we will execute.

sp.speaker: Olinda
sp.l: Then heare what for your ſatisfaction,
And to preſerve your friendſhip I reſolve
Againſt my ſelfe, and 'tis not to be alter'd:
You are both brave gentlemen, Ile ſtill profeſſe it,
Both noble ſervants, for whoſe gentle offers,
The undeſerving, and the poore Olinda
Is ever bound; you love both, faire, and vertuouſly;
Would I could be ſo happy to content both:
Which ſince I cannot, take this reſolute anſwer;
Goe from me both contentedly, and he
That laſt makes his returne, and comes to viſit,
Comes to my bed. You know my will: farewell;
My heart's too big to utter more: come friend.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ile wait on you to your Coach.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You both look blank, I cannot blame you.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: We have our diſpatches.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Ile home.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: And Ile abroad again, Farewell. Exit Clarange and Lidian.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Farewell to yee.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Their blunted departure troubles me: I feare
A ſuddaine and a dangerous diviſion
Of their long love will follow: have you took
Your leave of faire Olinda? Enter Caliſte with a purſe.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: She is gone ſir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Had you brought news Liſander were return'd too,
I were moſt happy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: ●till upon L●ſander?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I know he loves me, as he loves his health:
And heaven knowes I love him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I finde it ſo:
For me you have forgot, and what I am to you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: O think not ſo If you had loſt a ſiſter,
You lock'd all your delights in, it would grieve you:
A little you would wander from the fondneſſe,
You ow'd your husband: I have loſt a friend,
A noble friend, all that was excellent
In man, or man-kinde, was contain'd within him.
That loſte my wife—

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Madam, your noble Father—
A ſee for my good newes.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why? what of him ſir?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Is lighted at the doore, and longs to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Attend him hither.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O my deare Liſander.
But Ile bee merry: lets meet him my Caliſte.

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.l: I hope Laſanders love will now be buried:
My father will bring joy enough for one moneth,
To put him out of his memorie.

div.stage: Enter Dorilaus, his arme in a ſcarffe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How doe you ſonne?
Bleſſe my faire child, I am come to viſit yee,
To ſee what houſe you keep, they ſay you are bountifull,
I like the noyſe well, and I come to trie it.
Ne're a great belly yet? how have you trifl'd?
If I had done ſo (ſonne) I ſhould have heard on't
On both ſides by Saint Denis.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You are nobly welcome ſir:
We have time enough for that.

sp.speaker: Dorilaus.
sp.l: See how ſhe bluſhes:
'Tis a good ſigne you'll mend your fault, how doſt thou,
My good Caliſte?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Well, now I ſee you ſir;
I hope you bring a fruitfulneſſe along with ye.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good luck, I never miſſe, I was ever good at it:
Your mother groand for't wench, ſo did ſome other,
But I durſt never tell.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How does your arme ſir?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Have you been let bloud of late?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Againſt my will ſir.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A fall deare father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, a Gun, deare daughter;
Two or three Guns; I have one herein my buttock,
'Twould trouble a Surgeons teeth to pull it out.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O me! O me!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay, if you fall to fainting,
'Tis time for me to trudge: art ſuch a coward,
At the meere name of hurt to change thy colour?
I have been ſhot that men might ſee clean through me
And yet I fainted not: beſides my ſelfe,
Here are an hoſpitall of hurt men for yee.

div.stage: Enter Servants wounded in ſeverall places.

sp.speaker: Cloan.
sp.l: What ſhould this wonder be?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am amaz'd at it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What think ye of theſe? they are every one hurt ſoundly,
Hurt to the proof, they are through, & through I aſſure ye;
And that's good game, they ſcorne your puling ſcratches.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Who did this ſir?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Leave crying, and Ile tell you,
And get your plaiſters, and your warme ſtupes ready:
Have you ne're a Shepheard that can tarre us over?
'Twill proove a buſineſſe elſe, we are ſo many.
Comming to ſee you, I was ſet upon,
I and my men, as we were ſinging frolickly,
Not dreaming of an ambuſh of baſe rogues,
Set on ith' forreſt, I have forgot the name—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Twixt this, and Fountaine-Bleiu?
In the wilde Forreſt?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The ſame, the ſame, in that accurſed Forreſt,
Set on by villaines, that make boot of all men.
The Peeres of France are pillage there, they ſhot at us,
Hurt us, un-hors'd us, came to the ſword, there plide us,
Oppreſt us with freſh multitudes, freſh ſhot ſtill,
Rogues that would hang themſelves for a freſh doublet,
And for a Skarlet Caſlock kill their fathers.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Lighted you among theſe?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Among theſe murtherers,
Our poore blouds were ingag'd: yet we ſtrook bravely,
And more then once or twice we made them ſhun us,
And ſhrink their rugged heads: but we were hurt all.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How came you off? for I even long to hear that.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: After our prayers made to heaven to help us,
Or to be mercifull unto our ſoules,
So neare we were. Alas poore wench, wipe, wipe.
See heaven ſends remedy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am glad 'tis come ſir,
My heart was even a bleeding in my body.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A curl'd haire gentleman ſtept in, a ſtranger,
As he rod by, belike he heard our bickering,
Saw our diſtreſſes, drew his ſword, and prov'd
He came to execute, and not to argue.
Lord what a lightning me thought flew about him,
When he once toſs'd his blade; in face Adonis,
While peace inhabited between his eye-browes:
But when his noble anger ſtirr'd his mettle,
And blew his firie parts into a flame,
Like Pallas, when ſhe ſits between two armies,
Viewing with horrid browes their ſad events,
Such then hee look'd: and as her ſhield had arm'd him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This man ſir were a friend to give an age for.
This gentleman I muſt love naturally:
Nothing can keep me off; I pray you goe on ſir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will, for now you pleaſe me: this brave youth,
This bud of Mars, for yet he is no riper,
When once he had drawne bloud, and fleſh'd his ſword,
Fitted his manly mettle to his ſpirit,
How he beſtirr'd him? what a lane he made?
And through their fierie Bullets thruſt ſecurely:
The hardned villaines wondring at his confidence,
Lame as I was I follow'd, and admir'd too,
And ſtirr'd, and laid about me with new ſpirit,
My men too with new hearts thruſt into action,
And down the rogues went.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I am ſtrook with wonder.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Remember but the ſtorie of ſtrong Hector,
When like to lightning he broke through his van-guard,
How the Greeks frighted ran away by Troops,
And trod downe Troops to ſave their lives: ſo this man,
Diſpers'd theſe ſlaves: had they been more and mightier,
He had come off the greater, and more wonder.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Where is the man, good ſir, that we may honor him?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: That we may fall in ſuperſtition to him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I know not that, from me he late departed,
But not without that pious care to ſee ſafe
Me, and my weak men lodg'd, and dreſs'd; I urg'd him
Firſt hither, that I might more freely thanke him:
He told me he had buſineſſe crav'd my pardon,
Buſineſſe of much import.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Know you his name?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That he deny'd me too: a vow had bard him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: In that he was not noble to be nameleſſe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Daughter you muſt remēber him when I am dead,
And in a noble ſort requite his piety,
'Twas his deſire to dedicate this ſervice
To your faire thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He knowes me then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I nam'd you,
And nam'd you mine: I think that's all his knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No name, no being?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now I am mad to know him:
Saving mine honour, any thing I had now
But to enjoy his ſight, but his bare picture;
Make me his Saint, I muſt needs honour him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I know his name.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: There's thy reward for't; ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: His man told me, but he deſir'd my ſilence.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O Jaſper ſpeak, 'tis thy good Maſters cauſe too:
We all are bound ingratitude to compell thee.

sp.speaker: Serv
sp.p: Liſander, Yes, I am ſure it was Liſander.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Liſander? 'twas Liſander.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Tis Liſander. O my baſe thoughts? my wicked?
To make queſtion this act could be another mans:
'Tis Liſander, a handſome timber'd man.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: My Liſander! was this friends abſence to bee mourn'd?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I grant it:
Ile mourne his going now, and mourne it ſeriouſly:
When you weep for him, ſir, Ile beare you company.
That ſo much honour, ſo much honeſty
Should be in one man, to doe things thus bravely,
Make me his Saint, to me give this brave ſervice:
VVhat may I doe to recompence his goodneſſe?
I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Come ſir, I know you are ſickly, ſo are your men.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe I am weake,
And fitter for a bed then long diſcourſes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You ſhall hear to morrow, to morrow provide Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Liſander—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: VVhat new fire is this? Liſander—Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: PRethee good Lancelot remember that
Thy Maſters life is in thy truſt, and therefore
Be very careful.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: I will loſe mine owne, rather then hazard yours.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Take what diſguiſe
You in your owne diſcretion ſhall think fitteſt,
To keep your ſelfe unknowne.

sp.speaker: * Lanc.
sp.l: I warrant yee;
'Tis not the firſt time I have gone inviſible:
I am as fine a Fairie in a buſineſſe
Concerning night-worke—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Leave your vanities:
VVith this purſe (which deliver'd,
You may ſpare your Oratory) convey this Letter to
Caliſte's woman.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: 'Tis a handſome girle, Miſtris Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I have made her mine. You know your work.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: And if I ſweat not in it,
At my returne diſcarde me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Liſand.
sp.l: O Caliſte! the faireſt! cruelleſt!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: So early ſtirring? a good day to you.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I was viewing ſir,
The ſite of your houſe, and the handſomneſſe about it:
Believe me it ſtands healthfully and ſweetly.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: The houſe and maſter of it really
Are ever at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I returne it:
Now if you pleaſe goe forward in your ſtorie
Of your deare friend and Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I will tell it,
And tell it ſhort, becauſe 'tis breakfaſt time,
(And love a tedious thing to a quick ſtomach)
You eate not yeſter-night.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I ſhall endure ſir.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: My ſelfe (and as I then deliver'd to you)
A gentleman of noble hope, one Lidian,
Both brought up from our infancy together,
One company, one friendſhip, and one exerciſe,
Ever affecting, one bed holding us,
One griefe, and one joy parted ſtill between us,
More then companions, twins in all our actions,
VVe grew up till we were men, held one heart ſtill:
Time call'd us on to Armes, we were one ſouldier,
Alike we ſought our dangers and our honours,
Gloried alike one in anothers nobleneſſe:
VVhen Armes had made us fit, we were one lover,
VVe lov'd one woman, lov'd without diviſion,
And woo'd a long time with one faire affection;
And ſhe, as it appeares, loves us alike too.
At length conſidering what our love muſt grow to,
And covet in the end, this one was parted,
Rivalls and honours make men ſtand at diſtance.
VVe then woo'd with advantage, but were friends ſtill,
Saluted fairely, kept the peace of love,
We could not both enjoy the Ladies favour,
Without ſome ſcandall to her reputation,
We put it to her choice, this was her ſentence,
To part both from her, and the laſt returning
Should be her Lord; we obey'd, and now you know it;
And for my part, (ſo truely I am touch'd with't)
I will goe farre enough, and be the laſt too,
Or ne're returne:

sp.speaker: Liſand.
sp.l: A ſentence of much cruelty;
But milde, compar'd with whats pronounc'd on me.
Our loving youth is borne to many miſeries.
What is that Lidian pray ye?

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.p: Caliſte's brother, if ever you have heard of that faire Ladie.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: I have ſeen her ſir.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Then you have ſeen a wonder.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: I doe confeſſe: of what yeares is this Lidian?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: About my years: there is not much between us.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: I long to know him.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: 'Tis a vertuous longing,
As many hopes hang on his noble head,
As bloſſoms on a bough in May, and ſweet ones.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Ye are a faire ſtorie of your friend.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Of truth ſir: now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: There is a gentleman
At doore, would ſpeak with you on private buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: With me?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: He ſaies ſo, and brings haſte about him.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Wait on him in. Exit Serv.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: I will retire the while, to the next room.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: We ſhall not long diſturbe you. Ent. Alcidon.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Save ye ſir.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: The like to you fair ſir: pray you come neare.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Pray you inſtruct me for I know you not.
With Monſieur Clarange I would ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I am he ſir:
Ye are nobly welcome; I wait your buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Alcid.
sp.l: This will informe you.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Will you pleaſe to ſit down? Reads.
He ſhall command me ſir, Ile wait upon him
Within this houre.

sp.speaker: Alcid.
sp.l: Y'are a noble gentleman,
Wil't pleaſe you bring a friend? we are two of us,
And pitty either ſir ſhould be unfurniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I have none now, and the time is ſet ſo ſhort,
'Twill not be poſsible.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Doe me the honour:
I know you are ſo full of brave acquaintance,
And worthy friends, you cannot want a partner:
I would be loath to ſtand ſtill ſir; beſides,
You know the cuſtome, and the vantage of it,
If you come in alone.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And I muſt meet it.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Send, wee'l defer an houre, let us be equall:
Games won and loſt on equall tearmes ſhew faireſt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis to no purpoſe to ſend any whither,
Unleſſe men be at home by Revelation:
So pleaſe you breath a while; when I have done with him
You may be exercis'd too: Ile trouble no man.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: They are very loud. Now what's the newes?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I muſt leave you,
Leave you a while, two houres hence Ile returne friend.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: A little buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: And't be but a little, you may take me with ye.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Twill be a trouble to you.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: No indeed, to do you ſervice, I account a pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I muſt alone.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Clarang.
sp.l: 'Tis neceſsity—
Before you paſſe the walks, and back agen,
I will be with ye.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: If it be not unmannerly
To preſſe you, I would goe.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Ile tell you true ſir,
This gentleman and I upon appointment,
Are going to viſit a Lady.

sp.speaker: Liſond.
sp.l: I am no Capuchin, why ſhould not I goe?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Take the gentleman,
Come he may ſee the gentlewoman too,
And be moſt welcome, I do beſeech you take him.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: By any means, I love to ſee a gentlewoman,
A prettie wench too.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Well ſir, wee'll meet you,
And at the place: My ſervice to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: I kiſſe your hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Prethee read o're her Letter.

sp.speaker: Liſander

body.p: I Know you have conſider'd the dark ſentence Olinda gave us, and that (however ſhe diſguis'd it) it pointed more at our ſwords edges then our bodies baniſhments; the laſt muſt enjoy her: if we retire, our youths ars loſt in wandring; in emulation we ſhall grow old men, and feeble, Which is the ſcorne of love, and ruſt of honour, and ſo return more fit to wed our Sepulchers, then the Saint we aime at; let us therefore make our journey ſhort, and our hearts rea|dy, and with ou● ſwords in our hands put it to fortune, which ſhall be worthy to receive that bleſſing, Ile ſtay you on the mountaine, our old hunting place, this gentleman alone runs the hazzard with me, and ſo I kiſſe your hand.

sp.l: Is this your wench? you'll finde her a ſharp Miſtris.
What have I thruſt my ſelfe into? is this that Lidian
You told me of?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: My Ladies brother?
No cauſe to heave my ſword againſt but his?
To ſave the father yeſterday, and this morning,
To help to kill the ſon? this is moſt courteous?
The onely way to make the daughter doat on me.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Why doe you muſe? would ye goe off?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: No, no, I muſt on now; this will be kindly taken;
No life to ſacrifice, but part of hers?
Doe you fight ſtraight?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Yes, preſently.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: To morrow then,
The balefull tidings of this day will break out,
And this nights Sun will ſet in bloud; I am troubl'd:
If I am kill'd, I am happy.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: VVill you goe friend?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I am ready ſir, fortune thou haſt made me monſtrous. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Your couſin, and my true friend, luſty Leon,
Shall know how you uſe me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Be more temperate,
Or I will never uſe, nor know you more
Ith' way of a ſeruant: all the houſe takes notice
Of your ridiculous fopperie; I have no ſooner
Perform'd my duties in my Ladies chamber,
And ſhe ſcarce down the ſtaires, but you appeare
Like my evill ſpirit to me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Can the fiſh live out of the water, or the Salamander
Out of the fire? or I live warme, but in
The frying-pan of your favour?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Pray you forget
Your curious compariſons, borrowed from
The pond, and kitchin, and remember what
My Ladies pleaſure is forth' entertainment
Of her noble father.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: I would learn the art of memory in your table book.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Very good ſir, no more but up and ride, I apprehend
Your meaning, ſoft fire makes ſweet mault ſir:
I'le anſwer you in a Provetbe,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But one kiſſe from thy honey lippe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You ſight too high, my hand is
A faire aſcent from my foot, his ſlavering kiſſes
Spoyle me more gloves,—enough for once, you'l ſurfet
With too much grace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Have you no imployment for me?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yes, yes, go ſend for Leon, and convey him
Into the private Arbour, from his mouth
I heare your praiſes with more faith.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I am gone-yet one thing ere I go, there's at the dore
The rareſt Fortune-teller, he hath told me
The ſtrangeſt things; he knows ye are my Miſtris,
And under ſeale deliver'd how many children
I ſhall beget on you, pray you give him hearing,
He'l make it good to you.

sp.speaker: Gla.
sp.l: A cunning man
Of your own making, howſoe're I'le heare him
At your intreaty.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Now I perceive ye love me,
At my entreaty, come in friend—remember
To ſpeake as I directed, he knows his leſſon,
And the right way to pleaſe her; this it is
To have a head-peece. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lancelot like a Fortune-teller, with a Purſe, and two Letters in it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis ſaid you can tell Fortunes to come.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yes Miſtris, and what's paſt;
Unglove your hand, by this ſtraight line, I ſee
You have laine crooked.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How? laine crooked?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yes; and in that poſture plaid at the old game,
(No body heares me, and I'le be no blab)
And at it loſt your maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A ſhrewd fellow;
'Tis truth, but not to be confeſſ'd; in this
Your palmeſtry deceaves you, ſome thing elſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ye are a great woman with your Lady, and
Acquainted with her counſels.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Still more ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: There is a noble Knight Liſander loves her,
Whom ſhe regards not▪ and the deſtinies
With whom I am familiar, have deliver'd
That by your meanes alone, he muſt enjoy her.
Your hand agen, Yes, yes; you have already
Promis'd him your aſſiſtance, and what's more,
Taſted his bounty, for which, from the skye
There are 200. crownes dropp'd in a Purſe,
Looke backe, you'l find it true; nay, open it,
'Tis good Gold I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How, two Letters? the firſt indorſ'd to me? this to my Lady?
Subſcrib'd Liſander.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And the Fortuneteller, his ſervant Lancelot.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How had I loſt my eyes,
That I could not know thee? not a word of the loſſe
Of my virginity.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: Nor who I am.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I'le uſe all ſpeedy meanes for your diſpatch,
With a welcome anſwer, but till you receive it,
Continue thus disguis'd, Mounſieur Malfort
(You know the way to humour him) ſhall provide
A lodging for you, and good entertainment;
Nay, ſince we trade both one way, thou ſhalt have
Some feeling with me, take that.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Bountifull wench may'ſt thou ne're want imployment.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nor ſuch pay boy. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lidian, Alcidon, (at one dore) Liſander, Clarange, (at another.)

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: You'r welcome.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Let us do our office firſt,
And then make choice of a new peece of ground
To try our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: All's faire here.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: And here, their ſwords are equall.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: If there be any odds in mine, we will exchange.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Wee'l talke of that
When we are farther off, farwell.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Farewell friend. Ex. Liſand. and Alcid

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Come let us not be idle?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I will find you imployment, feare not.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: You know ſir, the cauſe that brings us hether

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: There needs no more diſcourſing,
No time, nor place for repetition now.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Let our Swords argue, and I wiſh Clarange,
The proud Olinda ſaw us.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Would ſhe did;
What ever eſtimation ſhe holds of me,
She ſhould behold me like a man fight for her.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: 'Tis nobly ſaid; ſet on love; and my fortune—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The ſame for me, come home brave Lidian,
'Twas manly thruſt, this token to the Lady,
Ye have it ſir, deliver it, take breath,
I ſee ye bleed apace, ye ſhall have faire play.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: You muſt lye there a while, I cannot help you,

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Nay, then my fortunes gone, I know I muſt dye:
Yet dearely will I ſell my love, come on both,
And uſe your fortunes, I expect no favour;
Weake as I am, my confidence ſhall meet ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yeild up your cauſe and live.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: What doſt thou hold me?
A recreant, that prefers life before credit?
Though I bleed hard, my honour finds no Iſſue,
That's conſtant to my heart.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Have at your life then.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Hold, or I'le turne, and bend my ſword againſt ye;
My cauſe Clarange too, view this brave Gentleman,
That yet may live to kill you, he ſtands nobly,
And has as great a promiſe of the day
As you can tye unto your ſelfe, he's ready,
His Sword as ſharpe, view him with that remembrance,
That you deliver'd him to me Clarange:
And with thoſe eyes, that clearneſſe will become ye:
View him, as you reported him; ſurvey him,
Fixe on your friendſhip ſir, I know you are noble,
And ſtep but Inward to your old affection,
Examine but that ſoule grew to your boſome,
And try then if your Sword will bite, it cannot,
The edge will turne againe, aſham'd, and blunted;
Lidian, you are the patterne of faire friendſhip,
Exampled for your Love, and imitated,
The Temple of true hearts, ſtor'd with affections,
For ſweetneſſe of your ſpirit made a Saint,
Can you decline this nobleneſſe to anger?
To mortall anger? 'gainſt the man ye love moſt?
Have ye the name of vertuous, not the nature?

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: I will ſit downe.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: And I'le ſit by you Lidian.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: And I'le go on, can heaven be pleas'd with theſe things?
To ſee two hearts that have been twin'd together
Married in friendſhip to the world, to wonder,
Of one growth, of one nouriſhment, one health,
Thus mortally divorc'd for one weake woman?
Can love be pleas'd? love is a gentle ſpirit,
The wind that blowes the Aprill flowers, not ſofter;
She is drawne with doves to ſhew her peacefulneſſe,
Lions and bloudy Pards are Mars's ſervants;
Would ye ſerve love? do it with humbleneſſe,
Without a noiſe, with ſtill prayers, and ſoft murmurs;
Upon her Altars offer your obedience,
And not your brawles; ſhe's won with teares, not terrors:
That fire ye kindle to her deity,
Is only gratefull when it blowes with ſighs,
And holy Incenſe flung with white hand-innocence;
Ye wound her now; ye are too ſuperſtitious,
No ſacrifice of bloud, or death ſhe longs for:

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Came he from heaven?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: He tels us truth good Lidian.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: That part of Noble love which is moſt ſweet,
And gives eternall being to faire beauty,
Honour. You hack a peeces with your ſwords,
And that ye fight to crowne, ye kill faire credit.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Thus we embrace, no more fight, but all friendſhip,
And where love pleaſes to beſtow his benefits,
Let us not argue.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Nay brave ſir, come in too;
You may love alſo, and may hope, If he do,
And not rewarded for't, there is no juſtice;
Farwell friend, here let's part upon our pilgrimage,
It muſt be ſo, Cupid draws on our ſorrowes.
And where the lot lights—

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: I ſhall count it happineſſe,
Farewell deare friend.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Firſt, let's relieve the Gentleman
That lyes hurt in your cauſe, and bring him off,
And take ſome cure for your hurts, then I will part too,
A third unfortunate, and willing wanderer. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: My feares foreſaw't would come to this.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I would your ſentence had been milder.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: 'Tis paſt helpe now.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I ſhare in your deſpaire, and yet my hopes
Have not quite left me, ſince all poſſible meanes
Are practiſed to prevent the miſchiefe following
Their mortall meeting, my Lord is coaſted one way,
My father, though his hurts forbad his travell,
Hath tooke another, my brother in Law Beronte,
A third, and every minute we muſt looke for
The certaine knowledge, which we muſt endure
With that calme patience heav'n ſhall pleaſe to lend us.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Dead both?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Such is the rumour, and 'tis generall.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: I heare my paſſing-bell.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am in a feavour.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: They ſay their ſeconds too; but what they are,
Is not known yet, ſome worthy fellows certain.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Where had you knowledge?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Of the Country people, 'tis ſpoken every where.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I heard it ſo too;
And 'tis ſo common, I do halfe beleeve it,
You have loſt a brother wench, he lov'd you well,
And might have liv'd to have done his countrie ſervice,
But he is gone, thou feld'ſt untimely Lidian,
But by a valiant hand, that's ſome ſmall comfort,
And tooke him with thee too, thou lov'ſt brave company,
Weeping will do no good, you loſt a ſervant,
He might have liv'd to have been your Maſter Lady,
But you fear'd that.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Good ſir, be tender to me,
The newes is bad enough, you need not preſſe it.
I lov'd him well, I lov'd 'em both.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It ſeemes ſo.
How many more have you to love ſo Lady?
They were both fooles to fight for ſuch a Fidle;
Certaine there was a dearth of noble anger,
When a ſlight woman was thought worth a quarrell.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Pray you thinke nobler.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: I'le tell thee what I thinke, the plague, war, famine,
Nay put in dice and drunkenneſſe, and thoſe
You'l grant are pretty helpes, kill not ſo many
(I meane ſo many noble) as your loves do,
Rather your lewdneſſe, I crave your mercy women.
Be not offended if I anger ye.
I am ſure ye have touch'd me deep, I came to be merry,
And with my children, but to ſee one ruin'd
By this fell accident—are they all dead?
If they be, ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: What newes?

div.stage: Enter Beronte, Alcidon, Clarinda, following with a letter,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What dead? ye poſe me;
I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: My brother Lidian, Clarange, and their ſeconds.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Here is one of 'em, and ſure this Gentleman's alive.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: I hope ſo, ſo is your ſon ſir, ſo is brave Clarange:
They fought indeed, and they were hurt ſufficiently;
We were all hurt, that bred the generall rumour,
But friends againe all, and like friends we parted.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Heard ye of Liſander?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes, and miſſ'd him narrowly:
He was one of the combatants, fought with this Gentleman,
Second againſt your brother, by his wiſdome
(For certainly good fortune followes him)
All was made peace, I'le tell you the reſt at dinner,
For we are hungry.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: I before I eate
Muſt pay a vow I am ſworne to; my life Madam
Was at Liſander's mercy, I live by it;
And for the noble favour, he deſir'd me
To kiſſe your faire hand for him, offering
This ſecond ſervice as a Sacrifice
At the Altar of your vertues.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Come, joy on all ſides;
Heaven will not ſuffer honeſt men to periſh.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Be proud of ſuch a friend.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Forgive me Madam,
It was a griefe might have concern'd you neare too.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: No worke of excellence but ſtill Liſander,
Go thy waies worthy.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Wee'l be merry too,
Were I to ſpeake againe, I would be wiſer. ** Ex. Manet. Cal. Clarin. ſtayes Caliſt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Too much of this rare cordiall makes me ſick,
However I obey you.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Now or never is an apt time to move her, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.l: Your ſervant, I would ſpeake with your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why doſt thou looke about?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I have private buſineſſe
That none muſt heare but you. Liſander—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Nay, is not here, but would entreat this favor,
Some of your Balſome from your own hand given,
For he is much hurt, and that he thinkes would cure him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He ſhall have all, my prayers too.

sp.speaker: Clarind.
sp.l: But conceive, me,
It muſt be from your ſelfe immediately,
Pitty ſo brave a Gentleman ſhould periſh,
He is ſuperſtitious, and he holds your hand
Of infinite power: I would not urge this Madam,
But only in a mans extreames, to helpe him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Let him come (good wench) 'tis that I wiſh, I am happy in't,
My husband his true friend, my noble father,
The faire Olinda, all deſire to ſee him;
He ſhall have many hands.

sp.speaker: Clarind.
sp.l: That he deſires not,
Nor eyes, but yours to looke upon his miſeries,
For then he thinkes 'twould be no perfect cure (Madam)
He would come private.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How can that be here?
I ſhall do wrong unto all thoſe that honour him,
Beſides my credit.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Dare ye not truſt a hurt man?
Not ſtraine a curteſie to ſave a Gentleman?
To ſave his life that has ſav'd all your family?
A man that comes like a poore mortifi'd Pilgrim;
Only to beg a bleſſing, and depart againe?
He would but ſee you, that he thinkes would cure him.
But ſince you find fit reaſons to the contrary,
And that it cannot ſtand with your cleare honour,
Though you beſt know how well he has deſerv'd of ye:
I'l ſend him word backe, though I grieve to do it,
Grieve at my ſoule, for certainly 'twill kill him,
What your will is.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Stay, I will thinke upon't; where is he wench?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: If you deſire to ſee him,
Let not that trouble you, he ſhall be with ye,
And in that time, that no man ſhall ſuſpect ye;
Your honour Madam, is in your own free keeping;
Your care in me, in him all honeſty;
If ye deſire him not, let him paſſe by ye:
And all this buſineſſe reckon but a dreame.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Go in, and counſell me, I would faine ſee him,
And willingly comfort him.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: 'Tis in your power.
And if you dare truſt me, you ſhall do it ſafely,
Read that, and let that tell you, how he honours you.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Clarinda, with a Key, and Leon.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: THis happy night. Kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Preſerve this eagerneſſe
Till we meet nearer, there is ſomething done
Will give us opportunity.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Witty girle, the plot?

sp.speaker: Clarind,
sp.l: You ſhall heare that at leaſure,
The whole houſe reeles with joy at the report
Of Lidians ſafety, and that joy increas'd
From their affection to the brave Liſander,
In being made the happy inſtrument to compound
The bloudy difference.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: They will heare ſhortly that
Will turne their mirth to mourning, he was then
The principall meanes to ſave two lives, but ſince
There are two falne, and by his ſingle hand,
For which his life muſt anſwer, if the King,
Whoſe arme is long, can reach him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: We have now no ſpare time to heare ſtories, take this key,
'Twill make your paſſage to the banquetting houſe
I' the garden free.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You will not faile to come?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: For mine owne ſake ne're doubt it? now for Li|ſander. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Dorilaus, Cleander, Servants with lights.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: To bed, to bed, 'tis very late.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: To bed all, I have dranke a health too much,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You'l ſleep the better,
My uſuall phiſicke that way.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Where's your Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: She is above, but very ill and aguiſh:
The late fright of her brother, has much troubl'd her;
She would entreate to lye alone.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Her pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Commend my love to her, and my prayers for her health,
I'le ſee her ere I goe. Ex. Manet Clarin.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: All good reſt to ye:
Now to my watch for Liſander, when he's furniſh'd,
For mine own friend, ſince I ſtand Centinell,
I love to laugh i'th' evenings too, and may,
The priviledge of my place will warrant it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: You have done well hetherto; where are we now?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Not far from the houſe, I heare by th'owles,
There are many of your welch falkoners about it;
Here were a night to chooſe to run away with
Another mans wife, and do the feate.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Peace knave,
The houſe is here before us, and ſome may heare us;
The candles are all out.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: But one i'the parlor,
I ſee it ſimper hether, pray come this way.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Step to the garden doore, and feele and 't be open.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I am going, lucke deliver me from the ſaw pits,
Or I am buried quicke: I heare a dog,
No, 'tis a cricket, ha? here's a cuckold buried,
Take heed of his horns ſir, here's the doore, 'tis open.

sp.speaker: Clarinda
sp.l: Whoſe there?

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: Friend.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sir, Liſander?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Ye are welcome, follow me, and make no noiſe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Go to your horſe, and keep your watch with care, ſirah
And be ſure ye ſleep not. Ex. Liſan. Clarin.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: Send me out the dairy-maid
To play at trump with me, and keep me waking,
My fellow horſe, and I now muſt diſcourſe
Like two learned Almanack-makers, of the ſtars,
And tell what a plentifull year 'twil prove of drunkards,
If I had but a pottle of Sacke, like a ſharp prickle,
To knock my noſe againſt when I am nodding,
I ſhould ſing like a Nightingall, but I muſt
Keepe watch without it, I am apt to dance,
Good fortune guide me from the faires circles. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Clarinda with a Taper, and Liſander with a Piſtole, two Chaires ſet out.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Come neare, Caliſte ſitting behind a Curtaine.
I'le leave ye now, draw but that Curtaine,
And have your wiſh; now Leon I am for thee.
We that are ſervants muſt make uſe of ſtoln houres,
And be glad of ſnatch'd occaſions. Exit.

sp.speaker: Liſand.
sp.l: Shee is aſleepe,
Fierce love hath clos'd his lights, I may looke on her,
Within her eyes 'has lock'd his graces up,
I may behold and live; how ſweet ſhe breathes?
The orient morning breaking out in odors,
Is not ſo full of perfumes, as her breath is;
She is the abſtract of all excellence, and ſcornes a paralell.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Your ſervant, your moſt obedient ſlave (adored Lady)
That comes but to behold thoſe eyes againe,
And pay ſome vowes I have to ſacred beauty,
And ſo paſſe by; I am blind as ignorance,
And know not where I wander, how I live,
Till I receive from their bright influence
Light to direct me, for devotions ſake,
You are the Saint I tread theſe holy ſteps to.
And holy Saints are all relenting ſweetneſſe;
Be not imag'd nor be not angry with me;
The greateſt attribute of heaven is mercy;
And 'tis the crowne of juſtice, and the glory
Where it may kill with right, to ſave with pitty.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why do you kneele, I know you come to mock me,
T' upbraid me with the benefits you have giv'n me,
Which are too many, and too mighty ſir,
For my returne; and I confeſſe 'tis juſtice,
That for my cruelty you ſhould deſpiſe me,
And I expect however you are calme now,
A foyle you ſtrive to ſet your cauſe upon,
It will breake out; Caliſte is unworthy,
Coy, proud, diſdaine full, I acknowledge all,
Colder of comfort than the frozen North is,
And more a ſtranger to Liſanders worth,
His youth and faith then it becomes her gratitude,
I bluſh to grant it, yet take this along,
A ſoveraigne medicine to allay diſpleaſure,
May be an argument to bring me off too;
She is married, and ſhe is chaſte; how ſweet that ſounds?
How it perfumes all ayre 'tis ſpoken in?
O deare Liſander, would you breake this union?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: No, I adore it: let me kiſſe your hand,
And ſeale the faire faith of a Gentleman on it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You are truly valiant, would it not afflict you
To have the horrid name of coward touch you?
Such is the whore to me.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I nobly thanke ye;
And may I be the ſame when I diſhonour ye;
This I may do againe. Kiſſing her hand.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ye may, and worthily;
Such comforts maids may grant with modeſty,
And neither make her poore, nor wrong her bounty;
Noble Liſander, how fond now am I of ye?
I heard you were hurt.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: You dare not heale me Lady?
I am hurt here; how ſweetly now ſhe bluſhes?
Excellent objects kill our ſight, ſhe blinds me;
The roſes in the pride of May ſhew pale to her;
O tyrant cuſtome! and O coward honour!
How ye compell me to put on mine owne chaines?
May I not kiſſe ye now in ſuperſtition?
For you appeare a thing that I would kneele to:
Let me erre that way. Kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ye ſhall erre for once, I have a kind of noble pity on you,
Among your manly ſufferings, make this moſt,
To erre no farther in deſire, for then ſir,
Ye adde unto the gratitudes I owe you;
And after death, your deare friends ſoule ſhall bleſſe you.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I am wondrous honeſt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I dare try. Kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I have taſted a bleſſedneſſe too great for dull mortality
Once more and let me dye.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I dare not murther,
How will maids curſe me if I kill with kiſſes?
And young men flye th' embraces of faire virgins?
Come pray ſit down, but let's talke temperately.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Is my deare friend a bed?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes, and aſleep;
Secure aſleep, 'tis midnight too Liſander,
Speake not ſo loud.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: You ſee I am a Statue,
I could not ſtand elſe as I had eaten Ice,
Or tooke into my bloud a drowzie poyſon,
And natures nobleſt, brighteſt flame burne in me;
Midnight? and I ſtand quietly to behold ſo?
The alarme rung, and I ſleep like a coward?
I am worne away, my faith, and dull obedience
Like crutches, carry my decayed body
Down to the grave, I have no youth within me,
Yet happily you love too.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Love with honour.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Honour? what's that? 'tis but a ſpecious title
We ſhould not prize too high.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Dearer than life.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: The value of it, is as time has made it,
And time and cuſtome have too far inſulted,
We are no Gods, to be alwaies tyed to ſtrictneſſe,
'Tis a preſumption to ſhew too like 'em;
March but an houre or two under loves enſignes,
We have examples of great memories —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: But foule ones too, that greatneſſe cannot cover;
That wife that by example ſins, ſins double,
And puls the curtaine open to her ſhame too;
Me thinkes to enjoy you thus—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: 'Tis no joy Lady,
A longing bride if ſhe ſtop here, would cry,
The Bridegroome too, and with juſt cauſe curſe Hymen;
But yeild a little, be one houre a woman,
(I do not ſpeake this to compell you Lady)
And give your will but motion, let it ſtirre
But in the taſte of that weake feares call evill,
Try it to underſtand it, wee'l do no thing,
You'l never come to know pure good elſe.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Fie ſir.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I have found a way, let's ſlip into this errour
As Innocents, that know not what we did;
As we were dreaming both let us embrace;
The ſin is none of ours then, but our fancies;
What have I ſaid? what blaſphemie to honour?
O my baſe thoughts! pray ye take this and ſhoot me.
My villaine thoughts? Noiſe within.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I weep your miſerie, and would to heaven-what noiſe?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: It comes on louder.
Kill me, and ſave your ſelfe; ſave your faire honour,
And lay the fault on me, let my life periſh,
My baſe laſcivious life, ſhoote quickely Lady,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Not for the world, retire behind the hangings,
And there ſtand cloſe —my husband, cloſe Liſander.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Deareſt, are you well? Enter Cleander with a Taper.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O my ſad heart; my head, my head.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Alas poore ſoule! what do you out of your bed?
You take cold my Caliſte: how do ye?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Not ſo well ſir to lye by ye, my brothers fright—

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: I had a frightfull dreame too,
A very frightfull dreame my beſt Caliſte:
Me thought there came a Dragon to your Chamber,
A furious Dragon (wife) I yet ſhake at it:
Are all things well?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Shall I ſhoote him?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No. All well Sir.
'T was but your care of me, your loving care,
Which alwaies watches.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: And me thought he came
As if he had riſen thus out of his den,
As I do from theſe hangings.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Dead.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hold good Sir.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: And forc'd ye in his armes thus.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Twas but fancie
That troubled ye, here's nothing to diſturbe me,
Good ſir to reſt againe, and I am now drouſie,
And will to bed; make no noiſe deare husband,
But let me ſleep: before you can call any body I am a bed.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: This, and ſweet reſt dwell with ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Come out againe, and as you love Liſander,
Make haſte away, you ſee his mind is troubled:
Do you know the doore ye came at?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Well ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And can ye hit it readily?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I warrant ye;
And muſt I go? muſt here end all my happineſſe?
Here in a dreame, as if it had no ſubſtance?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: For this time friend, or here begin our ruines;
We are both miſerable.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: This is ſome comfort
In my afflictions; they are ſo full already,
They can find no encreaſe.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Deare ſpeake no more.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: You muſt be ſilent then.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Farewell Liſander, thou joy of man farewell.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Farewell bright Lady,
Honour of woman-kind, a heavenly bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Be ever honeſt.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: I will be a dog elſe;
The vertues of your mind I'le make my library,
In which I'le ſtudy the celeſtiall beauty:
Your conſtancie, my armour that I'le fight in:
And on my ſword your chaſtity ſhall ſit,
Terror to rebell bloud.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Once more farewell: Noiſe within.
O that my modeſtie cou'd hold you ſtill ſir, —he comes againe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Heaven keep my hand from murther,
Murther of him I love.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Away deare friend,
Down to the garden ſtaires, that way Liſander,
We are betrai'd elſe. Ent. Clea.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Honour guard the Innocent. Exit. Liſ.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Stil up? I fear'd your health.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Has miſſ'd him happily;
I am going now▪ I have done my meditations,
My heart's almoſt at peace.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: To my warme bed then.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I will pray ye lead. A Piſtoll ſhot within

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A Piſtoll ſhot i'th' houſe?
At theſe houres? ſure ſome theefe, ſome murtherer:
Riſe ho, riſe all, I am betraide.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O fortune!
O giddy thing! he has met ſome oppoſition,
And kil'd; I am confounded, loſt for ever. Enter Dorilaus

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Theeves, my noble father, villaines, and Rogues.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Indeed, I heard a Piſtoll, let's ſearch about.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To bed againe, they are gone ſir,
I will not bid you thanke my valour for't;
Gone at the garden doore; there were a dozen,
And bravely arm'd, I ſaw 'em.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I am glad, glad at the heart.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: One ſhot at me, and miſſ'd me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No, 'twas at me, the bullet flew cloſe by me,
Cloſe by my eare; another had a huge Sword,
Flouriſh'd it thus; but at the point I met him,
But the Rogue taking me to be your Lordſhip,
(As ſure your name is terrible, and we
Not much unlike in the darke) roar'd out aloud,
'Tis the kill cow Dorilaus, and away
They ran as they had flowne: now you muſt love me,
Or feare me for my courage wench.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: O Rogue?
O lying Rogue, Liſander ſtumbled Madam,
At the ſtaires head, and in the fall the ſhot went off;
Was gone before they roſe.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I thanke heaven for't.

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.l: I was frighted too, it ſpoyl'd my game with Leon.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You muſt ſit up; and they had come to your Chamber
What pranks would they have plaid: how came the doore open?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I heard 'em when they forc'd it; up I roſe,
Took Durindana in my hand; and like
Orlando, iſſu'd forth.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I know you are valiant.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: To bed again.
And be you henceforth provident, at ſun-riſing
We muſt part for a while.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: When you are a bed,
Take leave of her, there 'twill be worth the taking;
Here 'tis but a cold ceremony, ere long
Wee'l find Liſander, or we have ill fortune.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Locke all the doores faſt.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Though they all ſtood open,
My name writ on the doore, they dare not enter. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Claran, Frier with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Turnd Hermit?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Yes, and a devout one too: I heard him preach.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: That leſſens my beliefe,
For though I grant my Lidian a ſcholler
As far as fits a Gentleman, he hath ſtudied
Humanity, and in that he is a Maſter;
Civility of manners, courtſhip, Armes;
But never aim'd at (as I could perceive)
The deep points of divinity.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: That confirmes his
Devotion to be reall, no way tainted
With oſtentation, or hypocriſie,
The cankers of Religion; his ſermon
So full of gravity and with ſuch ſweetneſſe
Deliver'd, that it drew the admiration
Of all the hearers on him; his own letters
To you, which witneſſe he will leave the world,
And theſe to faire Olinda, his late Miſtris,
In which he hath with all the moving language
That ever expreſſ'd Rhetorick, ſollicited
The Lady to forget him, and make you
Bleſſed in her embraces, may remove
All ſcrupulous doubts.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: It ſtrikes a ſadneſſe in me,
I know not what to thinke of't.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Ere he entred
His ſollitary cell, he pen'd a ditty,
His long and laſt farewell to love, and women,
So feelingly, that I confeſſe however
It ſtands not with my order to be taken
With ſuch Poeticall raptures; I was mov'd,
And ſtrangely with it.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Have you the copy?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Yes ſir:
My Novice too can ſing it, if you pleaſe
To give him hearing.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: And it will come timely,
For I am full of melancholy thoughts,
Againſt which I have heard with reaſon Muſick
To be the ſpeedieſt cure, pray you apply it.
ADieu fond love farewell you wanton powers,
I am free againe;
Thou dull diſeaſe of bloud and Idle howers.
Bewitching paine,
Flie to the fooles that ſigh away their time.
My nobler love to heaven clime,
And there behold beauty still young,
That time can ne're corrupt, nor death deſtroy;
Immortall ſweetneſſe by faire Angels ſung,
And honour'd by eternity and joy:
There lives my love, thether my hopes aſpire;
Fond love declines, this heavenly love growes higher.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: How do ye approve it?

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: To its due deſert,
It is a heavenly Hymne, no ditty father,
It paſſes through my eares unto my ſoule,
And workes divinely on it; give me leave
A little to conſider; ſhall I be
Out done in all things? nor good of my ſelfe.
Nor by example? ſhall my looſe hopes ſtill,
The viands of a fond affection, feed me
As I were a ſenſuall beaſt, ſpirituall food
Refuſ'd by my ſicke pallat? 'tis reſolv'd.
How far off father, doth this new made Hermit
Make his abode?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Some two dayes journey ſon.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Having reveal'd my faire intentions to ye,
I hope your piety will not deny me
Your aides to further 'em?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: That were againſt a good mans charity.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: My firſt requeſt is,
You would ſome time, for reaſons I will ſhew you,
Defer delivery of Lidians Letters
To faire Olinda.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Well ſir.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: For what followes,
You ſhall direct me; ſomething I will do,
A new borne zeale, and friendſhip prompts me to. Ex.

div.stage: Enter Dorilaus, Cleander, Chamberlaine, Table, Tapers, and three ſtooles.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: We have ſupp'd well friend; let our beds be ready,
We muſt be ſtirring early,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: They are made ſir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I cannot ſleep yet, where's the joviall hoſt
You told me of? 'tas been my cuſtome ever
To parley with mine hoſt.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: He's a good fellow,
And ſuch a one I know you love to laugh with;
Go call your Maſter up.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: He cannot come ſir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is he a bed with his wife?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: No certainly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Or with ſome other gheſts?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Neither and 't like ye.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Why then he ſhall come by your leave my friend,
I'le fetch him up my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Indeed you'l faile ſir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is he i'th' houſe?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: No, but he is hard by ſir;
He is faſt in's grave, he has been dead theſe three weekes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then o' my conſcience he will come but lamely,
And diſcourſe worſe.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Farewell mine honeſt Hoſt then,
Mine honeſt merry Hoſt; will you to bed yet?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, not this houre, I prethee ſit and chat by me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Give us a quart of wine then, wee'l be merry.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A match my ſon; pray let your wine be living,
Or lay it by your Maſter.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: It ſhall be quick ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Has not mine Hoſt a wife?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A good old woman.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Another coffine, that is not ſo hanſome;
Your Hoſteſſes in Innes ſhould be blith things,
Pretty, and young to draw in paſſengers;
She'l never fill her beds well, if ſhe be not beauteous.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: And curteous too. Enter Chamberlaine with wine.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I, I, and a good fellow,
That will miſtake ſometimes a Gentleman
For her good man; well done; here's to Liſander.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My full love meets it; make fire in our lodgings,
Wee'l trouble thee no farther; to your Son. Ex. Cham.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Put in Clarange too; off with't, I thanke ye;
This wine drinkes merrier ſtill, O for mine Hoſt now,
Were he alive againe, and well diſpos'd,
I would ſo claw his pate.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Y'are a hard drinker.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I love to make mine Hoſt drunke, he will lye then
The rareſt, and the roundeſt, of his friends,
His quarrels, and his gheſts, and they are the beſt bauds too
Take 'em in that tune.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You know all.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I did ſon, but time, and armes have worne me out

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: 'Tis late ſir, I heare none ſtirring. A lute is ſtruck.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Hark, what's that, a Lute?
'Tis at the doore I thinke.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: The doores are ſhut faſt.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis morning ſure, the Fidlers are got up
To fright mens ſleepes, have we ne're a piſpot ready?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Now I remember, I have heard mine Hoſt that's dead,
Touch a lute rarely, and as rarely ſing too,
A brave ſtill meane.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I would give a brace of French Crownes
To ſee him riſe and Fidle.
TIs late and cold, ſtirre up the fire;
Sit cloſe, and draw the Table nigher;
Be merry, and drinke wine that's old,
A hearty medicine 'gainst a cold.
Your beds of want on downe the beſt,
Where you ſhall tumble to your reſt;
I could wiſh you wenches too,
But I am dead and cannot do;
Call for the beſt the houſe may ring,
Sacke, White, and Claret let them bring,
And drinke apace while breath you have,
You'l find but cold drinke in the grave;
Plover, Patridge for your dinner,
And a Capon for the ſinner,
You ſhall find ready when you are up,
And your horſe ſhall have his ſup:
Welcome ſhall flye round,
And I ſhall ſmile though under ground.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Harke, a Song, now as I live, it is his voice.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He ſings well, the devill has a pleaſant pipe.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: The fellow lyed ſure, Enter Hoſt.
He is not dead, he's here: how pale he lookes?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is this he?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: You are welcome noble Gentlemen,
My brave old gheſt moſt welcome.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Lying knaves,
To tell us you were dead, come ſit downe by us,
We thanke ye for your Song.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Would 't had been better.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Speake, are ye dead?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Yes indeed am I Gentlemen,
I have been dead theſe three weekes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then here's to ye, to comfort your cold body.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: What do ye meane? ſtand further off.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will ſtand nearer to him,
Shall he come out on's coffin to beare us company,
And we not bid him welcome? come mine Hoſt,
Mine honeſt Hoſt, here's to ye.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Spirits ſir, drinke not?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Why do ye appeare?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: To waite upon ye Gentlemen,
'Thas been my duty living, now my farewell;
I feare ye are not us'd accordingly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I could wiſh you warmer company mine Hoſt,
How ever we are us'd?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Next to entreate a courteſie,
And then I goe to peace.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Is't in our power?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Yes and 'tis this, to ſee my body buried
In holy ground, for now I lye unhallowed,
By the clarkes fault; let my new grave be made
Amongſt good fellowes, that have died before me,
And merry Hoſtes of my kind.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And forty ſtoopes of wine dranke at thy funerall.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Do you know our travell?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Yes, to ſeeke your friends,
That in afflictions wander now.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Seeke 'em no farther, but be confident
They ſhall returne in peace.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: There's comfort yet.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Pray ye one word more, is't in your power mine Hoſt,
Anſwer me ſoftly, ſome houres before my death,
To give me warning?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I cannot tell ye truly,
But if I can, ſo much alive I lov'd ye,
I will appeare againe, adieu. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Adieu ſir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I am troubl'd; theſe ſtrange apparitions are
For the moſt part fatall.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This if told, will not
Find credit, the light breakes a pace, let's lye downe
And take ſome little reſt, an houre or two,
Then do mine hoſtes deſire, and ſo returne,
I do beleeve him.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: So do I, to reſt ſir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Is the houſe well ordered?
The doores look'd to now in your Maſters abſence?
Your care, and diligence amongſt the Servants?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I am ſtirring Madam.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: So thou art Clarinda,
More then thou ought'ſt I am ſure, why doſt thou bluſh?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I do not bluſh.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why doſt thou hang thy head wench?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Madam, ye are deceiv'd, I looke upright,
I underſtand ye not: ſhe has ſpied Leon, aſide.
Shame of his want of caution.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Looke on me; what, bluſh againe?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: 'Tis more then I know Madam;
I have no cauſe that I find yet.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Examine then.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Your Ladyſhip is ſet I thinke to ſhame me.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Do not deſerve't. who lay with you laſt night?
What bedfellow had ye? none of the maids came neare ye.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Madam they did.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Twas one in your Coſins cloathes then,
And wore a ſword; and ſure I keep no Amazons;
Wench do not lye, 'twill but proclame thee guilty;
Lyes hide our ſins like nets; like perſpectives,
They draw offences nearer ſtill, and greater:
Come tell the truth.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: You are the ſtrangeſt Lady
To have theſe doubts of me; how have I liv'd Madam?
And which of all my carefull ſervices deſerves theſe ſhames?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Leave facing? 'twill not ſerve ye,
This impudence becomes thee worſe then lying?
I thought ye had liv'd well, and I was proud of't▪
But you are pleas'd to abuſe my thoughts; who was't?
Honeſt repentance yet will make the fault leſſe.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Do ye compell me? do you ſtand ſo ſtrict too?
Nay, then have at ye; I ſhall rub that ſore Madam▪
(Since ye provoke me) will but vexe your Ladyſhip;
Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I will know.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: For your own peace,
The peace of your owne conſcience aske no farther;
Walke in, and let me alone.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No, I will know all.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Why, then I'le tell ye, 't was a man I lay with,
Never admire, 'tis eaſie to be done, Madam,
And uſuall too, a proper man I lay with;
Why ſhould you vexe at that? young as Liſander,
And able too; I grudge not at your pleaſure,
Why ſhould you ſtir at mine? I ſteale none from ye,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And doſt thou glory in this ſin?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.p: I am glad on't, to glory in't is for a mighty Lady That may command.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why didſt thou name Liſander?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Does it anger ye? does it a little gall ye?
I know it does, why would ye urge me Lady?
Why would ye be ſo curious to compell me?
I nam'd Liſander as my preſident,
The rule I err'd by, you love him, I know it,
I grudg'd not at it, but am pleas'd it is ſo;
And by my care and diligence you enjoy'd him.
Shall I for keeping counſell, have no comfort?
Will you have all your ſelfe? ingroſſe all pleaſure?
Are ye ſo hard hearted? why do ye bluſh now Madam?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My anger bluſhes, not my ſhame baſe woman.

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.l: I'le make your ſhame bluſh, ſince you put me to't
Who lay with you t'other night?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: With me? ye monſtor.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Whoſe ſweet embraces circled ye? not your husbands;
I wonder ye dare touch me in this point Madam?
Stir her againſt ye in whoſe hand your life lies?
More then your life your honour? what ſmug Amazon
Was that I brought you? that maid had ne're a petticoat?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: She'l halfe perſwade me anon, I am a beaſt too,
And I miſtruſt my ſelfe, though I am honeſt
For giving her the Helme, thou knoweſt Clarinda,
(Ev'n in thy conſcience) I was ever vertuous;
As far from luſt in meeting with Liſander
As the pure wind in welcoming the morning;
In all the converſation I had with him,
As free, and innocent, as you'd faire heaven;
Didſt not thou perſwade me too?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Yes, I had reaſon for't,
And now you are perſwaded I'le make uſe on't.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If I had ſin'd thus, and my youth entic'd me,
The nobleneſſe and beauty of his perſon,
Beſide the mighty benefits I am bound to,
